title: How to Stop Hair Loss: Do Natural Treatments Work?

steps.title: Follow the Mediterranean diet to lower your risk for alopecia.
steps.content: Follow the Mediterranean diet to lower your risk for alopecia. Alopecia is a general term for many types of hair loss, and it can make hair fall out on different spots around your body. You’ve probably heard that the Mediterranean diet can help with all kinds of health problems, and you can add hair loss to that list. Particularly, the raw vegetables and fresh herbs in that diet can prevent alopecia from starting. Try switching over to a Mediterranean diet rich in vegetables and herbs to see if this helps treat your hair loss. [2] X Research source The Mediterranean diet also includes lean proteins, fish, healthy oils, and fruits while cutting out fatty and processed foods.

steps.title: Eat at least 1,200-1,500 calories per day.
steps.content: Eat at least 1,200-1,500 calories per day. Even if you’re getting the right nutrients, your hair could stop growing if you don’t eat enough calories each day. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source If you follow a restricted diet and your hair starts thinning, this could be the reason. In general, always eat 1,200-1,500 calories daily so your hair has enough energy to grow correctly. [4] X Trustworthy Source National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Research and education center within the National Institutes of Health Go to source If you have trouble tracking your calories, there are plenty of apps that can help.

steps.title: Get plenty of vitamins from your regular diet.
steps.content: Get plenty of vitamins from your regular diet. Vitamin A, B, D, and E all help your hair grow and deficiencies could cause hair loss. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Make sure you have plenty of vitamin-rich foods in your diet to prevent any deficiencies. Some of the best vitamin sources include citrus fruits, peppers, leafy green vegetables, dairy, eggs, and whole grains. You can also get vitamin B and D from fish and meat. [6] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Protect your hair with selenium.
steps.content: Protect your hair with selenium. Selenium is another nutrient that helps protect your hair and could prevent it from falling out. The recommended daily selenium dose is 55 mcg, so try to get all you can from your normal diet. You can get selenium from meat, nuts, and vegetables. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Most people get plenty of selenium as long as they follow a healthy diet. Eating too much selenium could be toxic, so doctors don’t recommend selenium supplements.

steps.title: Include iron-rich foods in your diet.
steps.content: Include iron-rich foods in your diet. The exact relationship between iron and hair growth isn’t well-known. However, many people with hair loss do also have iron deficiencies, so it could play a role. Make sure you eat plenty of iron-rich foods to prevent any problems. [8] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Adult men need about 8 mg and women need 18 mg of iron per day. You can get this from red meat and poultry, fish, beans, lentils, leafy green vegetables, and nuts. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Get enough zinc.
steps.content: Get enough zinc. A zinc deficiency could also cause alopecia, so make sure you get enough from your regular diet. [10] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source The recommended amount is 8-11 mg per day, which you can get from seafood and oysters, red meat, beans, nuts, and fortified cereals. [11] X Research source You could also take zinc supplements to fix a deficiency. Ask your doctor before taking any supplements to make sure you take the right amount.

steps.title: Take vitamin supplements if you don’t get enough from your regular diet.
steps.content: Take vitamin supplements if you don’t get enough from your regular diet. While most people get enough vitamins from their diet, not everyone does. If you have deficiencies of vitamin A, B, D, or E and aren’t getting enough from your diet, then supplements may help strengthen your hair. [12] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Always ask your doctor before taking any supplements because they’ll probably only work if you have nutrient deficiencies. In some cases, getting too much of certain nutrients can actually cause hair loss too. [13] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Try a saw palmetto supplement.
steps.content: Try a saw palmetto supplement. Strong evidence is lacking, but there is some evidence that this herb could help support hair growth. You can try this for yourself to see if it helps. [14] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Fight alopecia with a biotin supplement.
steps.content: Fight alopecia with a biotin supplement. Biotin is a B vitamin that supports nail and hair growth. It’s a common ingredient in natural remedies for hair loss, and might help fight alopecia. Try a vitamin blend containing 3 mg of biotin, 30 mg of zinc, 200 mg of vitamin C, and less than 1 mg of folic acid to see if this helps. [15] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can also get biotin naturally from foods that are high in vitamin B like fish, poultry, eggs, nuts, seeds, and vegetables.

steps.title: Take ginseng extract to see if this works.
steps.content: Take ginseng extract to see if this works. This one has mixed results, but some studies show that ginseng can stimulate hair growth in mice and other animals. Ginseng is safe to try, so you can see if it works for you. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Common ginseng extract doses range from 100 to 800 mg, so always follow dosing instructions on the product you use. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Massage essential oils into your scalp.
steps.content: Massage essential oils into your scalp. You can add hair loss to the list of problems that essential oils might be able to treat. One study showed that thyme, rosemary, lavender, and cedarwood massaged into the scalp daily can help improve alopecia. Remember to mix the oil with a carrier oil like jojoba or olive to avoid irritation. [18] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Regular scalp massage for about 4 minutes a day, even without essential oils, could also help stimulate hair growth. [19] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Don't use unverified home remedies on your hair.
steps.content: Don't use unverified home remedies on your hair. If you search around the internet, you'll probably come across all kinds of home remedies to grow hair like onion juice or coconut oil. Unfortunately, there's no evidence that these remedies work, and some might even damage your scalp more. It's best to skip these and stick with recommended treatments instead. If you need more guidance, talk to a dermatologist. [20] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Wash and condition your hair with gentle products.
steps.content: Wash and condition your hair with gentle products. Using harsh products in your hair can make hair loss worse. Always use a gentle shampoo that won’t strip moisture from your hair, and finish up with a moisturizing conditioner to protect your hair. [21] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Also scrub your hair gently while you’re washing it. Pulling on it can put more stress on your roots. You can also use a leave-in conditioner to reduce breaking and split ends.

steps.title: Wear a loose hairstyle that doesn’t pull on your hair.
steps.content: Wear a loose hairstyle that doesn’t pull on your hair. You might not think your hairstyle has anything to do with hair loss, but it has more of an impact than you might think. One particular type of hair loss, traction alopecia, can come specifically from tight hairstyles that break off strands. Avoid this by wearing your hair down or in a loose style that doesn’t stress your roots. You can pull your hair back once in a while. The important thing is to avoid wearing your hair like that every day. Some hairstyles to avoid include cornrows, tight buns, dreadlocks, or tight braids. Also avoid pulling on your hair as a habit. This could damage it as well. [22] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Avoid using chemicals or high heat on your hair.
steps.content: Avoid using chemicals or high heat on your hair. Dying and other chemical treatments can damage your hair, as can high heat from blow-drying or curling. Avoid these treatments as much as possible to avoid making hair loss worse. [23] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source You can blow-dry your hair once in a while, but not every day. If you do, use the low heat setting. Try drying your hair with a towel instead.

steps.title: Quit smoking to protect your hair.
steps.content: Quit smoking to protect your hair. There is a clear link between smoking and hair loss. If you do smoke, then it’s best to quit as soon as possible. If you don’t, then don’t start at all. [24] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source
